author: Staff Reporter
text:
Experts in Public Health, entomology, sanitary engineering, government administration and voluntary organisations came together to discuss environmental sanitation and how it could be used to eradicate dengue in the city at a conference organised by the Tamil Nadu Health Development Association.

“The Aedes mosquitoes, which cause dengue, cannot fly over 100 m which is why there should be more focus on eradication at ground level. If we step in and prevent water stagnation at the local level in each area, it will have a greater impact,” said C.S. Rex Sargunam, President of the TNHDA.

Public assets

Echoing his views, M.R. Jaishankar, Society of Public Health and Environmental Engineers, stressed the need to carry out an audit of the public assets in each area.

“The sources of water stagnation are many — including abandoned buildings and tanks which very often, are ignored,” he explained.

Stating that while many infrastructural projects had capital expenditure, he pointed out that there were never provisions for maintenance costs which contributed to good environmental sanitation and could go a long way in preventing such disease outbreaks.

Recalling an initiative by the Corporation in 2005, M. Panneerselvam, former Chief Engineer, Chennai Corporation, said they de-silted all the canals including the Buckingham canal after nearly 30 years.
title: Experts discuss dengue eradication
